<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 734, 91]]<|/det|>
A student determines the mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of a metre ruler by a balancing method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 457, 122]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 131, 824, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 273, 532, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 146, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
The student places a circular load of mass \(M = 20 \text{g}\) on the metre ruler but in a position different from that shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 344, 806, 476]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 490, 591, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label> <label>(not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
Determine the distance \(d_0\) of the centre of the load from the zero end of the ruler, as shown in Fig. 1.2. Fig. 1.2 is **not** to scale.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 581, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d_0 = .................................................... \text{cm}\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The student places the metre ruler on the pivot and changes the position of the load so that the centre of the load is at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|> He adjusts the position of the metre ruler on the pivot until the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 164, 920, 183]]<|/det|> Describe a technique for ensuring that the ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 287, 181, 305]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 287, 875, 305]]<|/det|> The student determines the scale reading \(p\) on the ruler at the position of the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 303, 920, 336]]<|/det|> He calculates the distance \(a\) between the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot and the distance \(b\) between the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot, using the equations <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 350, 546, 368]]<|/det|> \[a = p - 5.0\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 381, 554, 399]]<|/det|> \[b = 50.0 - p.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 412, 764, 429]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure for values of \(M = 40 \text{g}, 60 \text{g}, 80 \text{g}\) and \(100 \text{g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 427, 479, 445]]<|/det|> His results are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 458, 541, 476]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 485, 712, 653]]<|/det|>
\(M/\mathrm {g}\)\(a/\mathrm {cm}\)\(b/\mathrm {cm}\)\(\frac {b}{a}\)
2039.55.5
4035.79.30.26
6032.612.40.38
8029.016.00.55
10027.018.00.67
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 666, 809, 691]]<|/det|> For the value of \(M = 20 \text{g}\), calculate and record in Table 1.1 the value of \(\frac{b}{a}\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 668, 920, 687]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 88, 144, 107]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 82, 546, 109]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(M / \mathrm{g}\) ( \(y\) -axis) against \(\frac{b}{a}\) ( \(x\) -axis).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 332, 137]]<|/det|>
Draw the best-fit line.

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 613, 920, 633]]<|/det|>
<form>G = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 181, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 644, 670, 663]]<|/det|>
The mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre ruler is numerically equal to \(G\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 675, 712, 694]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) in this experiment. Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 706, 920, 726]]<|/det|>
<form>M_{\mathrm{R}} = .................................................... [1]

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The determination of \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) by this method assumes that the centre of mass of the metre ruler is at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 150]]<|/det|>
Suggest how you could use apparatus from Fig. 1.1 to test whether the centre of mass of the metre ruler is at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 370, 920, 389]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 401, 181, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 401, 850, 420]]<|/det|>
A student finds that the centre of mass of her metre ruler is at the \(48.7 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 740, 451]]<|/det|>
Suggest how she changes the procedure in **(b)**(ii) to allow for this.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 555, 922, 574]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 861, 291]]<|/det|>
Suggest two precautions to take in this type of experiment to ensure accurate results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 170, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 917, 353]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 583, 920, 600]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 804, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the rate of cooling of hot water in a container which has a lid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effect of lids of different thicknesses on the rate of cooling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 398, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 182, 233, 197]]<|/det|>
· a beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 331, 214]]<|/det|>
· a supply of hot water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 532, 229]]<|/det|>
· insulating material from which lids can be cut.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 324, 259]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 457, 290]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 918, 320]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the rate of cooling can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 460, 336]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 920, 367]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 603, 383]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 576, 414]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.
